data.title: Expanding an object in the console after a step will show the wrong properties
data.body:
VS Code Insiders v1.8.

- Hit a breakpoint
- Eval something in the console that evaluates to an object
- Step again
- Expand the object in the console
- It will show the properties from another object, or nothing

VariableReferences are only valid between events returned from the debug adapter. For this reason the REPL may only uses handles returned from the evaluate requests until the next event occurs. When an event occurs the old objects showing in the REPL needs to be frozen and trying to drill deeper into them should be prevented.

data.title: Render MarkedString according to language server spec
data.body:
- surround content with backticks + language alias before tokenizing, then render using markdown TextMate grammar
- remove marked string rendering code duplication

forked from #16006, related to #3746

close #14166 (requires #16502 to get PHP syntax highlighting, also note that this does not address the debug eval issue alluded to in that thread. will address that separately, likely using a similar approach.)

cc @jrieken, @dbaeumer, @alexandrudima, @mjbvz

data.title: Fix markdown + PHP fenced code blocks
data.body:
- previously PHP wasn't working at all because we don't appear to properly support grammar injections. This issue was addressed by pointing to a specific repository key (#languages)
- ensure "fuzzy" syntax highlighting for PHP/HTML code so that script start tags are not required

forked from #16006, related to #14166

close #3746

data.title: Allow extensions to have visibility into the user's build command
data.body:
This feature request is required in order for IncrediBuild to be able to offer in its extension for VS Code the level of user experience we offer in Visual Studio.

IncrediBuild is the de-facto Visual Studio C++ \ XBox \ Android NDK **build acceleration** installed on more than 100,000 machines worldwide and as part of a partnership we've done with MS, IncrediBuild is offered as a freemium version as part of the VS2015 and soon VS2017 (any VS user can access IncrediBuild directly from within VS).

IncrediBuild is also used to accelerate a variety of compilers and build tools such as Make, Scons, ninja, Jom, Jam and many others.
 
IncrediBuild offers an extension inside IDEs allowing users to execute their builds in a distributed manner, seamlessly harnessing hundreds of idle CPUs they already own across their local network or public cloud to highly accelerate compilations \ tests \ code generation and any other compute intense process.
IncrediBuild effectively transforms the developer's 8 cores laptop into a virtual super computer with hundreds of cores and gigs of memory.

In order for IncrediBuild's VS Code extension to offer users the same seamless integration as offered in Visual Studio, we need to get as an input the build command that the user executes when compiling his project.
 
We can call VS Code's API function executeCommand to execute the 'workbench.action.tasks.build' command to build the project, however, we didn't find a way to have VS Code translate the command name to the full command line for IncrediBuild to execute.
 
We seek a way to convert the 'workbench.action.tasks.build' command to a full command line which we can feed to BuildConsole or any other way to get the full build command line to execute.

data.title: Test: ESLint support for file types other than JS
data.body:
Tests: 
- https://github.com/Microsoft/language-server-protocol/issues/125
- https://github.com/Microsoft/language-server-protocol/issues/126

Complexity: 3

- [x] macOS @kieferrm
- [x] any OS @bpasero  

Install ESLint from here:

To do so, download it and rename the zip to vsix. Then run code-insinder (e.g. code) --install-extension ./vscode-eslint-1.2.0.vsix to install the version of ESLint to test:

- create a new workspace
- install eslint and eslint-plugin-html using npm.
- open the workspace.
- run `ESLint - create .eslintrc.json file`
- add to it:
```json
    "plugins": [
        "html"
    ]
```
- create a HTML file
```
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
	<script>
		function foo() {
		}
		fo();
	</script>
</html>
```

Observe: no Errors are shown :-)

- open the workspace settings:
- add
```json
"eslint.validate": [
	"javascript", "javascriptreact", "html"
]
```

Observe: errors should be shown in the HTML file.

Play with the following features:

- remove  and add languages from "eslint.validate". The corresponding changes should be hot. E.g. errors disappear when removed and appear when added.
- ensure that you can remove `javascript` as well and JS files are not validated anymore.
- test other ESLint plugins (I know there are plugins for vue and TS files).
- test quick fixes and autofix on save (due to a bug in the HTML plugin this is still only available in JS). To do so make sure the following ESLint rule is enabled in the `.eslintrc.json`: `"no-extra-semi": "warn"`. Add extra semicolons and make sure that the light bulb appears. Execute actions from the light bulb.
- enable auto fix on save using the following workspace setting `"eslint.autoFixOnSave": true` (note as with format on save this is only available if ` "files.autoSave"` is off or on focus lost.). Ensure that fixes are applied on save and that the fixes are applied at the correct positions.

As per https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/16258 we have restyled the debug start action in the debug viewlet. Have a worskapce with a 'launch.json' and verify:
* debug start action looks nicely styled both in light and dark theme and shows hover feedback

data.title: Take out keymaps code from ExtensionsWorkbenchService
data.body:
The newly introduced keymaps code could and should be done by composing events from the several services into a new contribution, not by fitting it within the ExtensionsWorkbenchService's implementation details.

The new contribution should listen to `onEnablementChanged` from `IExtensionEnablementService` and `onDidInstallExtension` from `IExtensionManagementService` and make it work in an isolated file.

Additionally, if no caller of [`checkForOtherKeymaps`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/extensions/node/extensionsWorkbenchService.ts#L584) checks for its returning promise, it should just return `void` and perform the error handling inside.

data.title: Feature: Support multiple searches

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hi everybody.

Currently VSCode supports only one active search: I cannot look for multiple things at a time.
I often have need in this feature.
I can implement it myself if someone will guide me.
I suggest to add new tab "Searches", which looks like this:
![collapsed_searches](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11215191/20879396/a9d6fd40-bae4-11e6-9237-2ee4759a96c4.png)
And it expands to:
![expanded_searches](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11215191/20879407/b8e989c4-bae4-11e6-8515-7344506cc9ea.png)
Unfortunately, I haven't made a close button. Imagine there is a close button to the right of a search entry.
When a user starts a search, then an entry in the searches is created.
When a user clicks on a search entry, then the entry's search becomes active.
When a user clicks on the close button of a search entry, then the entry is deleted.

I am waiting for your opinions to this feature.

data.title: ALT-menu get hidden when clicking message button

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Win 7 Enterprise 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open menu with ALT-key
2. Select Help => Check for updates...
3. Try to click the "There are no updates currently available." Close button
4. The menu closes and you have to click the close button again

My expectation is for the message to disappear and the menu to stay visible the first time the close button is clicked.

data.title: Deselect one of multi-cursors

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Win7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Select all occurrences of current selection (Ctrl+Shift+L) or similar method (multiple Alt+click) - have two or more multi-cursors
2. Try to deselect one of multi-cursors

Is there a way of doing this?  

In Sublime and Atom, IIRC, it is the same shortcut for adding the cursors and to remove a cursor if you click on one of them.  
Following the same logic, vscode should remove the cursor with Alt+click, but I also tried various other combinations and nothing has worked.

data.title: Adding Docker 1.12 instructions to its grammar
data.body:
This simply updates the Docker grammar to include the `HEALTHCHECK` and `SHELL` commands which were introduced to Docker 1.12, and were added to the [grammar file](https://github.com/docker/docker/blob/4cb71f80823af345d063cf0ad657e73ce9caa75f/contrib/syntax/textmate/Docker.tmbundle/Syntaxes/Dockerfile.tmLanguage) that VS Code's copy is based on.

*Note that the alpha-sorting of the command names represents the majority of the code churn, and was done in order to sync with the aforementioned grammar in the Docker GitHub repo.*

data.title: Undo stops are created by cursor movement

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

I've just been updating my extension to make it so that automatic edits, made by the extension in between any two manual edits made by the user, are not included in the user's undo history and are simply removed as a batch as the user steps through the undo history made by their manual edits, so that the minor edits made by the extension are not given the same weight as a user's normal edits. Unfortunately, the `undoStopBefore` and `undoStopAfter` options seem to have no effect.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone the simple extension _autotrim_ from https://github.com/axefrog/vscode-autotrim
2. Modify [line 36 of extension.ts](https://github.com/axefrog/vscode-autotrim/blob/master/src/extension.ts#L36), disabling undo stops so that the code matches the code block further below.
3. Set up a text file with five lines of text, and some trailing spaces on lines 2, 3 and 4.
4. Test the extension in debug mode by making a change to line 1 and then using the arrow keys to move the cursor to line 5 and make another edit there. The extension will trim lines 2, 3 and 4 as it moves past them on the way to line 5.
5. Try and undo the edits to lines 5 and 1.

**Bug:** I'd expect the first undo to remove the edit to line 5, and the next undo to reverse all of the automatic changes to lines 2, 3, and 4, as well as the manual edit made to line 1. Instead, undo stops are also created for each line that was automatically trimmed by the extension, requiring several additional undos before the manual edit to line 1 is undone.

The code for line 36 should be:

```ts
editor.edit(ed => ed.replace(line.range, text), {undoStopBefore: false, undoStopAfter: false});
```
